author: undying1200
content:
Was there any decision made on how to prevent large drops in hashpower going into the merge? I know there were some solutions discussed here and the ACD channel, but my take away then was we were too far away to predict.

As we approach the merge now with the tapering off of new hashpower, combined with the now huge surplus of GPUs as miners have stopped buying and are now actively selling. Do we have enough information now to formulate a miner plan for the merge to insure network security and not becoming vulnerable to a 51% attack if hashrate drops precipitously just prior to the merge?

author: sky.cactus
content: If hashpower drops significantly, we can adjust the terminal total difficulty to compensate.

author: m.kalinin
content: I am not sure about miners actively selling, at least hash rate looks pretty stable https://etherscan.io/chart/hashrate

author: undying1200
content: Yeah I remember this being one of the solutions. But did it ever get put into an EIP? If not can it be added to the ice age extension to auto smooth difficulty for sudden drops over X period of time?

author: m.kalinin
content: It is in the EIP-3675 already, also, there is `TERMINAL_BLOCK_HASH` override which will be used in case of attacks near the merge and accelerate the merge by picking up an exact terminal PoW block and start building a PoS chain on top of it

author: highdensitydevices
content:
It is ironic role reversal that at the moment Ethereum finally needs the miners, we are now worried the miners have no reason to work with us. It is a shame we never tried to build a good business relationship with them and instead fought them on issues like EIP-1057 that was the only EIP they ever wanted or asked for.

If EIP-1559 was an example of what to expect when they lose income then I would not make any assumptions about a smooth merge when they have nothing to lose in a relationship that was always one sided. A relationship where they held up their part of the business relationship to keep the network secure only to be asked to take pay cuts as we became more successful. They were never expected to reap the rewards of success like everyone else did.

author: highdensitydevices
content: Hopefully going forward we will learn from our mistakes with the miners and come to respect stakers and the important role they play in securing the network. As a fellow staker and previous miner the time barriers to entry and notably exit are extremely low when staking versus mining. I am not all that confident we would keep stakers if we treat them like we did miners as they have no infrastructure or hardware to sell if they are not happy. Unhappy miners stuck with Ethereum all these years in a love hate relationship that would cost them too much to leave. With the click of the button the stakers could be gone in a flash, of course at a limited exit rate. There is much more competition for simple things like earning APR.
